title: Cromford Canal Walking Route

images.title: Stephen McKay [CC BY-SA 2.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Cromford Canal at Langley Mill during the summer of 2007. This was at one time the point where the Nottingham Canal joined the Cromford Canal, which in turn joined the Erewash Canal below the lock out of shot to the left. The Erewash Canal nowadays provides the only navigable access to this location. Until the 1990s this scene would have been in Nottinghamshire rather than Derbyshire, the area technically being known as Langley Bridge. The boundary was changed to follow a more logical course along the Eastwood by-pass rather than the River Erewash thus bringing the whole of Langley Mill into one parish.

images.title: Alan Heardman / Cromford Canal View
images.caption: Looking across Railway line, A6, River Derwent towards Shining Cliff Woods.

images.title: Nikki Mahadevan [CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)]
images.caption: Railway bridge over former course of Cromford Canal. This railway bridge for the dismantled Ambergate to Codnor line is situated at the eastern end of the car park of the Excavator pub on the A610, Buckland Hollow. Cromford canal used to flow under this bridge and also through the Buckland Hollow Tunnel, which leads under the Heage road. The tunnel can be found at the other end of the car park.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Cromford Canal
images.caption: The stretch just to the east of Leawood Aqueduct. The towpath now forms part of the Derwent Valley Heritage Way footpath. Crich Stand with the Sherwood Foresters memorial beacon can be seen in the distance.

images.title: Angella Streluk / Cromford Canal
images.caption: Near Cromford. The canal bought materials to Cromford Mill and took away the products. It is now a useful part of a circular walk in the area.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Cromford Canal
images.caption: The stretch just to the east of Leawood Aqueduct.This is no longer kept up to its original level. Just visible is the sluice which allows the canal to be drained into the River Derwent if necessary.

images.title: Ray Folwell / Footbridge over the Cromford Canal
images.caption: Footbridge over the canal. This takes the towpath across the canal near to the Lea Wood pump house.

description: Enjoy a waterside stroll along the Cromford Canal on this easy walk in Derbyshire. This section of the canal runs from Cromford to Ambergate and is designated as a Biological Site of Special Scientific Interest and a Local Nature Reserve. The walk passes the Leawood Pump House by the aqueduct over the River Derwent and a series of pretty bridges. You'll also pass Shining Cliff Woods and enjoy lovely views of the Derwent Valley. The walk makes use of the Derwent Valley Heritage Way so you could continue along this long distance walking route to extend your walk. The canal is located just a few miles south of Matlock .
